citations.narrative:
The facility uses cage cards as the form of identification for puppies under four months of age until the puppy can be
microchipped. Upon today’s inspection, the cage card for one puppy had not been completed in full with the required
information as outlined in this subpart.
Appropriate identification of dogs is necessary to meet recordkeeping requirements for inventory, disposition, transport,
and healthcare documentation. The facility must properly identify all dogs, including puppies, with an acceptable form of
identification as specified in this subpart.
Correct by January 15, 2026.

Upon inspection, one adult male Schnauzer had an empty water bowl. The licensee explained all water receptacles had
been filled when daily observations were last completed, refilling the one water bowl again while the inspector was
present. Constant access to potable water is necessary to ensure that dogs remain hydrated as needed throughout the
day. The facility must ensure that all dogs have continuous access to potable water, unless restricted by the attending
veterinarian or excepted as provided in 3.17(a).
The licensee corrected during the inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The facility uses cage cards as the form of identification for puppies under four months of age until the puppy can be 
microchipped. Upon today’s inspection, the cage card for one puppy had not been completed in full with the required 
information as outlined in this subpart.  
Appropriate identification of dogs is necessary to meet recordkeeping requirements for inventory, disposition, transport, 
and healthcare documentation. The facility must properly identify all dogs, including puppies, with an acceptable form of 
identification as specified in this subpart. 
 
Correct by January 15, 2026. 
3.10(a) 
   
Watering 
Upon inspection, one adult male Schnauzer had an empty water bowl. The licensee explained all water receptacles had 
been filled when daily observations were last completed, refilling the one water bowl again while the inspector was 
present. Constant access to potable water is necessary to ensure that dogs remain hydrated as needed throughout the 
day. The facility must ensure that all dogs have continuous access to potable water, unless restricted by the attending 
veterinarian or excepted as provided in 3.17(a). 
 
The licensee corrected during the inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
